In Julia, Write a function `timezone_bumper(dt,bump)` that increases any provided timestamp by `bump::Int` hours (defaults to +3 hours). Make sure it works only for DateTime types and throws an error for Date types.

```julia
function timezone_bumper(dt::DateTime, bump::Integer = 3)
    if typeof(dt) == DateTime
        return dt + Hour(bump)
    elseif typeof(dt) == Date
        error("Cannot increase date by time zone offset. Provide a 'DateTime' object to add time zone offset.")
    end
end
```

This function takes a `DateTime` object and an optional integer `bump` specifying the number of hours to add. By default, it adds 3 hours if no explicit value is provided for `bump`. The function returns another `DateTime` object with the time zone offset applied. If you try to pass a `Date` object instead of a `DateTime` object, an error will be thrown.
